A glorious sun is carved on the ceiling, directly above a pool of still water. The ceiling reflected in the pool doesn’t show a sun carving, but rather a moon carving.

The pool is a magic portal that connects to the pool in @UUID[.dxe352NdooKsMBhl]{area 19D}. Characters who immerse themselves in the pool surface in area 19D.

Moon Pool.name: Moon Pool
Moon Pool.text:
If the characters enter this room via the pool, read:

A full moon is carved on the ceiling here, directly above the pool. The walls are decorated with reliefs of the Omuan people carrying out daily chores.

The ceiling reflected in the pool doesn’t show a moon carving, but rather a sun carving. To travel back to @UUID[.CEng6QVK2OaL0bZI]{area 19C}, a character must duck under the pool’s surface.

Locked Secret Door. A secret door in the south wall requires a successful [[/check Perception 15 format=long]] to spot. Even when found, there’s no obvious way to open the door, although a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.1nhIxh0DsJsntCfj]{knock} spell works.

A character who studies the wall reliefs and succeeds on a [[/check Investigation 10 format=long]] observes that one of the figures on the wall is crafting a key. If the character pushes the key, the secret door pops open, revealing a dusty, web-filled tunnel (@UUID[.2VpfAe67Cnyol5qf]{area 19F}) beyond.

Chamber of Sacraments.name: Chamber of Sacraments
Chamber of Sacraments.text:
Eight torches illuminate this room. The light washes over a floor mosaic showing two creatures locked in combat: a small bear with sharp claws and a rabbit with a spiral horn on its forehead. In the middle of the room, a robed figure stands next to a waist-high pedestal, atop which rests a stone cube. The figure is bald and has one hand on the cube. It takes a moment to realize that the figure is a statue.

The floor mosaic shows Obo’laka (a zorbo) fighting I’jin (an almiraj). Inscriptions in Old Omuan underneath the mosaic explain how I’jin ruined Obo’laka’s attempt to placate Ubtao (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh3DwellersOf.JournalEntryPage.JFC5mUJCcUG2UYq1]{Legend of the Nine Gods}).

The statue is a petrified Red Wizard (LE male Thayan human mage) named @UUID[Actor.toaVoj0000000000]{Voj}. He failed to disarm the puzzle cube trap before touching it, and its magic turned him to stone. If a greater restoration spell or similar magic is cast on Voj, he reverts to flesh, realizes he’s not alone, and attacks anyone who would deny him the cube.

Voj takes orders from Zagmira and knows the legend of Obo’laka and I’jin. If the characters defeat him, they find some valuables on his person (see “Treasure” below) that aren’t obtainable while Voj is petrified.

Puzzle Cube. Any creature that touches the puzzle cube must make a [[/save con 15 format=long]] or be &Reference[petrified apply=false]{petrified}. Even on a success, a creature holding the cube must repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns until the puzzle cube is removed from the shrine. When the torches in this room are inserted into the empty brackets in @UUID[.LFEQJXbVKP1w4ZQC]{area 19B}, Obo’laka’s puzzle cube can be handled safely.

Torches. Each torch burns with a flame that never wears its wood down. The torches can be extinguished, but they reignite every time they reenter this chamber. Relighting a torch by any other method proves impossible. If all eight torches are inserted into the empty brackets in area 19B, the puzzle cube can be handled safely.

Treasure. Voj carries an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.eQNXan0zp279jDtk]{immovable rod}, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-tomb-annihilation.items.Item.uN5QsjtkcNKlNQgN]{leather pouch} containing three tiger eye gemstones (10 gp each), and a red, leather-bound @UUID[Compendium.dnd-tomb-annihilation.items.Item.XN9Le77w05zGDtWl]{spellbook}, which contains all the spells he has prepared.

Secret Passage.name: Secret Passage
Secret Passage.text:
This dark passage is choked with dust and webs. It’s clear that no one has been through here in years.

Traversing this corridor is the easiest way to transport the torches in @UUID[.uFteWwP3bL5xcwFu]{area 19E} to @UUID[.LFEQJXbVKP1w4ZQC]{area 19B} without dousing their flames in the pools. The secret door leading to area 19B has three wooden bars across it. Once the bars are removed, the door pulls open easily.

Royal Palace.name: Royal Palace
Royal Palace.text:
Thousands of bats swirl above a great ruin. Behind a 15-foot-high circular wall, you see crumbling arcades, vine-choked statues, empty plazas, and buildings overgrown with banyan roots. Streets that aren’t flooded are choked with rubble.

The palace looks abandoned and has been looted of all treasure. Snakes slithering through the rubble are mostly harmless (but see @UUID[.vABtzhu3JWMtL09C]{area 20A} and @UUID[.RHz08Kn195jC4KEh]{20B} below). The bats flying above the ruin are also harmless.

The Fane of the Night Serpent (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4FaneOfTheN]{chapter 4}) lies under the palace. There are two entrances: a large entrance to the north (area 20A) and a hidden entrance to the south (area 20B). Watching over each entrance are three @UUID[Compendium.dnd-tomb-annihilation.actors.Actor.toaYuantiMal1000]{type 1 yuan-ti malisons} in snake form. They slither out of hiding, revert to their true forms, and attack anyone who isn’t accompanied by yuan-ti.

Main Entrance to the Fane.name: Main Entrance to the Fane
Main Entrance to the Fane.text:
The north entrance to the Fane of the Night Serpent is easy to find:

A worked tunnel descends into the earth here. Muddy cart-tracks wind back and forth from the entrance.

The tunnel slopes down to @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.3km4oa3DrO3pBcBq]{area 1} of the yuan-ti temple (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi]{chapter 4}).

Secret Entrance to the Fane.name: Secret Entrance to the Fane
Secret Entrance to the Fane.text:
The south entrance to the Fane of the Night Serpent is hidden behind palms and thorny bushes. Yuan-ti who pass through here always try to cover their tracks. To find the entrance, a character must succeed on a [[/check perception survival 15 format=long]] while searching the vicinity.

Lifting aside the palm fronds, you uncover a narrow, rough-hewn passage descending into the earth.

This passage connects to @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.AzWRdttY6xXvOEnl]{area 23} of the yuan-ti temple (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi]{chapter 4}).

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
@Embed[JournalEntry.toaAppArtHandout.JournalEntryPage.74LyGM5PNRToYEHN]

Under the ruined palace of Omu lies a yuan-ti temple dedicated to an apocalyptic god known as Dendar the Night Serpent. The temple was originally part of the palace, but the yuan-ti have expanded and modified it to suit their needs over the years. When Ras Nsi steals one of Omu’s puzzle cubes (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh3DwellersOf]{chapter 3}), the characters must delve into the temple to recover it. Characters captured by yuan-ti also end up here.

Schemes of the Yuan-ti.name: Schemes of the Yuan-ti
Schemes of the Yuan-ti.text: Before running this chapter, review the information on yuan-ti in the Monster Manual. Additional information appears in Volo’s Guide to Monsters.

Getting Inside.name: Getting Inside
Getting Inside.text:
Temple Roster and Reinforcements

If the yuan-ti detect intruders inside the temple who aren’t prisoners, they try to ring the loud gong in @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.jDapyFVU0c9UoIBn]{area 9}. The @UUID[.a3GlQFiI4qhZlMrZ]{Temple Roster} table summarizes the positions of yuan-ti across the lair and indicates how they react when intruders are detected or the gong is struck.

Once an alarm is raised, begin tracking how much time the characters spend in the temple. At the end of each hour, roll percentile dice and consult the @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4FaneOfTheN.JournalEntryPage.jaYCew8FdeMJcaJP]{Temple Reinforcements} table to see what else arrives. Reinforcements enter the temple from @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.3km4oa3DrO3pBcBq]{area 1} or @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.AzWRdttY6xXvOEnl]{23} and behave as you desire.

The temple is a living community. Outside combat, inhabitants move between chambers, feed, wash, rest, and engage in all the villainous deceptions of yuan-ti life. You can use the Temple Reinforcements table to simulate this.

The two entrances to the yuan-ti temple are located amid the ruins of Omu’s royal palace (see chapter 3, @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh3LocationsI.JournalEntryPage.vrpydPTu1gGqpDmN]{area 20}). @UUID[Scene.toaCh3FaneoftheN]{Map 4.1} provides an overview of the temple. The main entrance leads to @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.3km4oa3DrO3pBcBq]{area 1} on the map, and the secret entrance leads to @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.AzWRdttY6xXvOEnl]{area 23}.

Adventurers are most likely to enter the temple as infiltrators or captives. If they’ve forged an alliance with the Red Wizards in @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh3DwellersOf]{chapter 3}, they’ll be looking for Zagmira’s spy in the temple harem (@UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.D8tgIAOgH2JB6cif]{area 10}).

Ras Nsi.name: Ras Nsi
Ras Nsi.text:
@UUID[Actor.zwk4UdGbwhWumFqp]{Ras Nsi} leads the yuan-ti of Omu on a divine mission to usher forth Dendar the Night Serpent and trigger the end of the world (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaAppDMonstersA.JournalEntryPage.FDyn4HWR2JU4EFY6]{appendix D} for more information on Ras Nsi and his evil plans). His version of the apocalypse is not imminent, since Ras Nsi is distracted with fears of his own mortality. He has fallen victim to the death curse and is growing weaker by the day, and neither he nor his yuan-ti priests have been able to ascertain the cause or find a remedy. As Ras Nsi’s power wanes, his rivals are preparing to dispose of him and continue their holy mission.

Acererak promised to help the yuan-ti if they would guard the Tomb of the Nine Gods. Ras Nsi doesn’t know that Acererak is playing him for a fool. If the characters convince Ras Nsi that Acererak is a common enemy, he is of a mind not to stand in their way, provided that they vow to destroy the Soulmonger. Above all else, Ras Nsi values his own life.

Fenthaza.name: Fenthaza
Fenthaza.text:
The cruel yuan-ti malison @UUID[Actor.toaFenthaza00000]{Fenthaza} is second in power only to Ras Nsi and serves as the temple’s high priest. As one of Dendar’s “nightmare speakers,” she interprets the dream visions of the serpent god and pleases her with torture and sacrifice.

Fenthaza has long resented Ras Nsi for hanging onto the threads of his humanity. Now her visions portend ruin at Ras Nsi’s hands, and she actively plots against him. Her dreams have revealed a treasure called the Black Opal Crown, hidden deep within the Tomb of the Nine Gods. She’s convinced that the crown is the key to unleashing Dendar the Night Serpent. Fenthaza wants to murder Ras Nsi and obtain the crown from the tomb. The priest is patient and cunning, and she won’t take action against Ras Nsi unless the odds are stacked in her favor. Captive characters soon become cat’s-paws in Fenthaza’s coup.

Infiltrating the Temple.name: Infiltrating the Temple
Infiltrating the Temple.text:
Human characters can pose as yuan-ti purebloods if they dress and act appropriately, and can even lead other characters into the temple as captives. They must bluff their way past the yuan-ti guards. Malisons are the easiest to fool: their inherent disdain for the lower strata of yuan-ti society means that they pay little heed to purebloods moving through the temple.

The temple denizens have racial tics that are difficult to mimic and they speak in a patois that combines the Common and Draconic tongues. To avoid drawing suspicion when talking, a human character pretending to be a yuan-ti pureblood must succeed on a [[/check Deception 15 format=long]].

Nonhumans have a much harder time fooling the yuan-ti without the aid of magic. Nonhuman characters attempting to pose as yuan-ti purebloods have disadvantage on any ability checks made to act in disguise.

Captured by the Yuan-ti.name: Captured by the Yuan-ti
Captured by the Yuan-ti.text:
Characters captured by the yuan-ti are stripped of their gear, fitted with manacles (one set binding the wrists and another binding the ankles), and confined to the pits in @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.c5KSrbfz8RBYkmuU]{area 8}. Their gear is stored in @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.riNQGMPil8ff5PZa]{area 13} until it can be studied and inventoried by the storeroom’s guardian, @UUID[Actor.toaAziMas0000000]{Azi Mas}.

If the characters don’t escape within 1 hour, they are visited by the yuan-ti spymaster @UUID[Actor.toaYahru00000000]{Yahru} and his bodyguards (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.yWQA4HhH9YSn8fQn]{area 17}). Yahru asks questions about their mission. He and his bodyguards then escort the characters to Ras Nsi or Fenthaza.

Yahru enjoys political games and uses the characters to play @UUID[Actor.zwk4UdGbwhWumFqp]{Ras Nsi} and @UUID[Actor.toaFenthaza00000]{Fenthaza} against one another. If the characters answered Yahru’s questions angrily or arrogantly, they are taken to Ras Nsi. If they reacted in a calm, civil manner, they are brought to Fenthaza.

Audience with Ras Nsi.name: Audience with Ras Nsi
Audience with Ras Nsi.text: Ras Nsi meets with prisoners in the throne room (@UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.levHlyIkCVBQVoEj]{area 11}). He wants to know why the characters invaded Omu. If he finds their answer unsatisfactory, he views them as dangerous and has them put to death immediately. If Ras Nsi learns that they’ve come to put an end to the death curse, he is intrigued. If they reveal that the cause lies in the Tomb of the Nine Gods, he releases them, gives them any remaining puzzle cubes they need to enter the tomb, and grants them safe passage out of Omu if they succeed in destroying the Soulmonger. He won’t help them further, since that could incite a yuan-ti revolt.

Audience with Fenthaza.name: Audience with Fenthaza
Audience with Fenthaza.text:
Fenthaza meets with prisoners in her quarters (@UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.2lhbMM1v5rItAt98]{area 5}). She sees the characters as pawns in her plot to overthrow Ras Nsi. To determine whether they can be trusted, she assigns them to work under Overseer Issar (@UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.48niaswQ2stR1tYB]{area 19}). Issar assigns each character a labor, determined by rolling percentile dice and consulting the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-tomb-annihilation.tables.RollTable.toaCh4LaborersTa]{Laborers’ Tasks} table. (More than one character can be given the same task.) As they perform labors, characters see how the temple functions and might find ways to escape.

If the characters perform their labors without incident or complaint for 1 day, they are brought before Fenthaza once more. She promises them their freedom if they agree to overthrow Ras Nsi. She also allows them to keep any puzzle cubes in Ras Nsi’s custody. If they agree, she gives them the armory passphrases (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.eZ4g0Yd4iVIDNq8d]{area 4}) and encourages them to carry out an uprising. She also offers to ritually transform human characters into yuan-ti purebloods so they can get closer to Ras Nsi (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.jDapyFVU0c9UoIBn]{area 9}). While the characters sow confusion, she assembles her guards and priests (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.aUnlR0zZ24aquGp1]{areas 6 }and @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.VkFxWEhIUsgsO2O6]{7}), ambushes Ras Nsi, and attempts to kill him.

If the coup is thwarted, Fenthaza and her confederates are put to death. If the coup succeeds, Fenthaza concludes that the characters have outlived their usefulness and tries to eliminate them. If the characters flee before she can betray them, Fenthaza sends her air elemental (see @UUID[JournalEntry.toaCh4Locationsi.JournalEntryPage.2lhbMM1v5rItAt98]{area 5}) to hunt them down and kill them.
